channel.title: Geel RSPS--317 server written in C#
channel.description:
Hey, so, I've been working on a server written in C# recently. This may be the first (I'm pretty sure it's not) to be written in C#, and I've been making a lot of headway with it. It uses .NET 4.0 and SQLite.
[b]Reason to use C# over Java:[/b] -VS2010 is easily 10X better than Eclipse -Reflection -Anonymous methods (lambdas). This may not seem important, but I absolutely love anonymous methods. In order to write an "anonymous" method in java, you need to create an entire interface and instantiate it. In C#, it's so much easier. It will make the job a lot easier. -Speed (debatable) -I have much more knowledge in C# than Java -Writing it in C# means I can't just copy paste entire classes; I will be forced to entirely understand the protocol.
[b]Expected features:[/b] -[b]External assembly support[/b]: This will allow somebody to write their own assembly (DLL) and stick it in their folder and the game will run it. This will allow them to manage minigames, skills, NPCs, etc. OUTSIDE of the "main game."
-[b]Dialogue system[/b]: This will be very easy to use, and will make heavy use of anonymous methods (see?). In just a few lines, one can write entire conversations.
-[b]"Individual" NPCs/objects[/b]: Not very "revolutionary," I imagine, but each NPC/Object (that needs to be) will be its own class--no massive switch statements for no reason.
-[b]SQLite player saving[/b]: Saves players in a database instead of individual text files; makes it easy to perform batch operations on players.
-[b]Unique method of cache editing[/b]:This is more of a client feature, but it allows me to modify the cache without actually touching the cache files themselves.
[b]What's done so far?[/b]
-Logging in -Moving around -Player update loop (also see other players) -Chat -Logging out -Player saving -Item actions -NPC management -NPC update loop -Dialogue -Item cache editing -NPC cache editing -Object cache editing -Object management
Some pictures: [img]http://puu.sh/tLC0[/img]
[img]http://puu.sh/uiqK[/img]
[img]http://puu.sh/uAuB[/img]

item.source: Geel RSPS--317 server written in C#

item.title: Geel RSPS--317 server written in C#
item.dc:creator: @geel9 geel9
item.description:
@geel9 wrote:

[quote=“object, post:21, topic:441756”]In Java you can use java.util.ServiceLoader<?> to find and load all implementations of the given generic type, provided that they’re in the classpath (and their constructors are public with no parameter arguments - well suited for an Abstract Factory). So you don’t have to use Reflection directly (only indirectly via that class). This approach is usually called SPI (short for Service Provider Interface), and it supports reloading on the fly (although I doubt it uses HotSwap).

Edit: I forgot to mention that you need to have it in a Jar file, with a META-INF/services/[INSERT_FILE_WITH_NAME_OF_GENERIC_TYPE_HERE_AND_NO_EXTENSION]. In that file you need to provide the implementing classes fully-qualified class-names, one per line (comments are possible too).[/quote]

C# makes it easier, in addition to having anonymous methods.

And I’m just more used to C# than Java.

Also Eclipse is the spawn of satan.

Read full topic
item.source: Geel RSPS--317 server written in C#

item.title: Geel RSPS--317 server written in C#
item.dc:creator: @Protosstribe object
item.description:
@Protosstribe wrote:

In Java you can use java.util.ServiceLoader<?> to find and load all implementations of the given generic type, provided that they’re in the classpath (and their constructors are public with no parameter arguments - well suited for an Abstract Factory). So you don’t have to use Reflection directly (only indirectly via that class). This approach is usually called SPI (short for Service Provider Interface), and it supports reloading on the fly (although I doubt it uses HotSwap).

Edit: I forgot to mention that you need to have it in a Jar file, with a META-INF/services/[INSERT_FILE_WITH_NAME_OF_GENERIC_TYPE_HERE_AND_NO_EXTENSION]. In that file you need to provide the implementing classes fully-qualified class-names, one per line (comments are possible too).

item.title: Geel RSPS--317 server written in C#
item.dc:creator: @geel9 geel9
item.description:
@geel9 wrote:

I recently added Item cache editing. It’s not true cache editing, as I don’t actually touch the cache files. Instead, I have a separate file that the client loads all item definitions from (as well as from the cache). When the client tries to get an item, I look to see if the item is in the new cache file. If it is, I return it.

This also allows me to create NEW items very easily.

Read full topic

item.title: Geel RSPS--317 server written in C#
item.dc:creator: @T41 t4
item.description:
@T41 wrote:

There’s only a few NPCs with specific attack patterns… It just seems more natural to have something like:

NPCTemplate
BasicNPC implements NPCTemplate
KBD implements NPCTemplate

NPCHandler

if npc contains special flag:
        lookup override from map and use it
else:
        use basic npc

Read full topic
item.source: Geel RSPS--317 server written in C#

item.title: Geel RSPS--317 server written in C#
item.dc:creator: @geel9 geel9
item.description:
@geel9 wrote:

[quote=“t4, post:16, topic:441756”][quote author=geel9 link=topic=544440.msg3991839#msg3991839 date=1336690907]

[quote author=_s link=topic=544440.msg3991792#msg3991792 date=1336686664]

java has reflection and the performance is on par with what C# can achieve, so they’re moot reasons

The reflection that I need (getting all subclasses of a class) is not possible.
[/quote]fair enough, it is possible but only through very hackish means that you are understandably avoiding. may i ask why you’re using reflection? a plugin system perhaps?

A plugin system is definitely planned, but I also wanted to be able to write a class for an NPC, and not have to write a line of code that adds it to the list of “coded” NPCs–it just is automatically added at runtime.
[/quote]why not just throw npc definitions in something like xml and allow overriding of behaviour for special NPCs ie. jad or the KQ

NPC “definitions” are stored in an SQLite database, and when I want to write code for NPCs, I don’t want to have to tell the code to add the NPC to a special table of “overridden” NPCs.

what[/quote]

So say I want to write custom code for the King Black Dragon. I’d make a new KingBlackDragon class, and make it extend the NPC class. Then I’d just override the OnAttack, OnTick, etc. methods. Now, how will the code know to call the KBD’s custom methods? Well, there’d need to be some list that defines what NPCs have custom methods. So instead of manually adding the KBD to the list, I’d have it generate it on startup by using reflection.

Read full topic

[quote author=_s link=topic=544440.msg3991733#msg3991733 date=1336682570]

java has reflection and the performance is on par with what C# can achieve, so they’re moot reasons

The reflection that I need (getting all subclasses of a class) is not possible.
[/quote]fair enough, it is possible but only through very hackish means that you are understandably avoiding. may i ask why you’re using reflection? a plugin system perhaps?

A plugin system is definitely planned, but I also wanted to be able to write a class for an NPC, and not have to write a line of code that adds it to the list of “coded” NPCs–it just is automatically added at runtime.
[/quote]why not just throw npc definitions in something like xml and allow overriding of behaviour for special NPCs ie. jad or the KQ[/quote]

NPC “definitions” are stored in an SQLite database, and when I want to write code for NPCs, I don’t want to have to tell the code to add the NPC to a special table of “overridden” NPCs.

item.title: Geel RSPS--317 server written in C#
item.dc:creator: @geel9 geel9
item.description:
@geel9 wrote:

Lin,

My mistake. I assumed C# was faster, and I was wrong. Although, it is still much faster to program in, for me.

I use .NET 4.0 because I just know if I switch to 2.0, I’m going to be missing something crucial (such as closures, maybe).

Also, I use VS2010 because I personally like the look. My computer is fast enough to handle any speed issues :V

Read full topic

item.title: Geel RSPS--317 server written in C#
item.dc:creator: @Lin Lin
item.description:
@Lin wrote:

Definitely not the first (Rarity) Good luck though. If you’re actually good with C#, perhaps we could team up someday.

Also, why VS10 and .NET Framework 4.0 over 2.0? I prefer 2008 because of its speed and look compared to 2010. Do you plan on using Linq or something else introduced in 4.0? I’m quite curious.

Also, don’t count on C# being notably faster than Java. You’ll pretty much get the same results.

Read full topic

item.title: Geel RSPS--317 server written in C#
item.dc:creator: @geel9 geel9
item.description:
@geel9 wrote:

Hey, so, I’ve been working on a server written in C# recently. This may be the first (I’m pretty sure it’s not) to be written in C#, and I’ve been making a lot of headway with it. It uses .NET 4.0 and SQLite.

Reason to use C# over Java:
-VS2010 is easily 10X better than Eclipse
-Reflection
-Anonymous methods (lambdas). This may not seem important, but I absolutely love anonymous methods. In order to write an “anonymous” method in java, you need to create an entire interface and instantiate it. In C#, it’s so much easier. It will make the job a lot easier.
-Speed (debatable)
-I have much more knowledge in C# than Java
-Writing it in C# means I can’t just copy paste entire classes; I will be forced to entirely understand the protocol.

Expected features:
-External assembly support: This will allow somebody to write their own assembly (DLL) and stick it in their folder and the game will run it. This will allow them to manage minigames, skills, NPCs, etc. OUTSIDE of the “main game.”

-Dialogue system: This will be very easy to use, and will make heavy use of anonymous methods (see?). In just a few lines, one can write entire conversations.

-“Individual” NPCs/objects: Not very “revolutionary,” I imagine, but each NPC/Object (that needs to be) will be its own class–no massive switch statements for no reason.

-SQLite player saving: Saves players in a database instead of individual text files; makes it easy to perform batch operations on players.

-Unique method of cache editing:This is more of a client feature, but it allows me to modify the cache without actually touching the cache files themselves.

What’s done so far?

-Logging in
-Moving around
-Player update loop (also see other players)
-Chat
-Logging out
-Player saving
-Item actions
-NPC management
-NPC update loop
-Dialogue
-Item cache editing
-NPC cache editing
-Object cache editing
-Object management

Some pictures:

Read full topic
